Children of cross-lineage parents express traits from one lineage dominantly, with subtle features from the other.

**Reproduction:** Khari fertility is high relative to their short lifespan (60-70 years). Three to five children per pair is average. Warren childcare is communal — every adult in the warren shares responsibility. The phrase "it takes a warren" is not metaphorical.

---

#### Rathai (Goblins)

**Attitude:** Practical, unsentimental, and organized. Rathai approach sex the same way they approach everything: it's a thing that happens, it's more enjoyable when done well, and overthinking it is a waste of time better spent on something productive.

**The Nettleworks context:** Dense urban living means privacy is scarce. A Rathai family of four sharing a 200-square-foot apartment does not have the luxury of pretending sex doesn't happen. Children learn about sex early — not through formal education but through proximity. The cultural attitude is demystification: sex is a physical act, it's enjoyable, it has consequences (pregnancy, emotional attachment, schedule disruption), and managing those consequences is your responsibility.

**Courtship:** Work-adjacent. Rathai meet partners through professional networks. The Nettleworks' guild structure means your colleagues are your social circle, and your social circle is your dating pool. A Rathai couple typically starts as coworkers, becomes friends, becomes more, and formalizes when they build something together (literally — the marriage custom is a shared project). Romantic gestures exist but tend toward the practical: fixing someone's Grimoire, bringing food to their shift, solving a problem they mentioned in passing.

**Sex itself:** Efficient. Not cold — Rathai are capable of passion and tenderness — but the culture prizes function. Rathai sexual slang is engineering metaphor ("good calibration," "smooth operation," "overheating") and this isn't entirely joking. The Nettleworks' professional sex workers advertise with precision: services offered, duration, price, client reviews. It's a service industry. Repeat clients are valued. Complaints are addressed. The Rathai find other races' mystification of sex commerce genuinely puzzling.

**Reproduction:** High fertility, short lifespan (50-60 years). Rathai reach physical maturity fast and reproduce early — first children at sixteen to twenty is normal. Families of four to eight are standard. The Nettleworks' population density is partly biological — Rathai simply produce more children than the space can comfortably hold. This drives the outward expansion into other cities' infrastructure, which drives the cycle of Rathai industrial indispensability.

---

#### Varrek (Gnomes)

**Attitude:** Measured. Varrek do not suppress sexual desire — they *schedule* it. A Varrek couple's intimate life is organized with the same precision they apply to everything else. This is not joyless — Varrek experience pleasure as intensely as anyone — but the cultural instinct to quantify and optimize extends into the bedroom. A Varrek who has identified what their partner enjoys will reproduce it with scientific accuracy. "Spontaneity" in Varrek sexual culture means trying something new, documenting the response, and incorporating the results.

**Courtship:** Intellectual. Varrek attraction begins with competence — watching someone solve a problem well is the most reliable trigger. The Gannavar phrase **verath-kindled** ("accuracy-sparked") means "I find your work so impressive it's become sexual." This is used unironically.

**Reproduction:** Moderate fertility, long lifespan (90-110 years). One to three children. Varrek approach pregnancy with characteristic planning — conception is typically deliberate, timed to career phases, and accompanied by a written child-raising plan that both parents review and revise. The child-raising plan is not legally binding. Every Varrek couple writes one anyway.

---

#### Oni

**Attitude:** Loud, celebratory, physical, and utterly without pretense. Oni treat sex the way they treat everything: as something to be done at full volume with maximum enthusiasm. Restraint is for people who haven't figured out what they want yet. An Oni who wants someone says so. An Oni who's having a good time makes sure everyone within earshot knows it.

**Festival culture:** The Grand Festival's seven days include an unofficial tradition on the fifth night — **the Warm Night** — where couples (established and newly formed) retreat from the main festival grounds to the highland hot springs. What happens at the springs is technically private. The noise carries. The festival-goers remaining at the main grounds toast each particularly audible moment. This tradition is not in any official Oni cultural record. Every Oni knows about it.

**Courtship:** The Challenge Toast (shared cup of lit spirit) is the marriage custom, but pre-marriage courtship follows the same pattern: a dare. An Oni interested in someone challenges them — to a drink, a fight, a climb, a contest. Accepting the challenge is accepting the interest. Winning the challenge earns the right to initiate. Losing earns respect, which in Oni culture, is almost as good.

**Sex itself:** Physically intense. Oni are larger and stronger than most races, and their baseline stamina exceeds human norms. An Oni encounter is long by most standards and physically demanding. Cross-racial partners report needing recovery time. The Oni find this flattering. Shared marks (similar to Gorundai tradition, likely a cultural exchange from centuries of Caldruun proximity) are common. Oni skin-singers sometimes incorporate intimate scars into tattoo narratives — a lover's mark woven into the body's autobiography.

**Reproduction:** Moderate fertility. Two to four children. Oni children are large at birth (8-12 pounds, human-equivalent births average 7-8), and Oni mothers are celebrated and supported by the entire clan during pregnancy and birth. A pregnant Oni receives the community's best food, a permanent seat at the fire, and absolute authority over the nearest cooking pot. Refusing a pregnant Oni anything is considered not just rude but *cosmically unwise.*

---

#### Lunarians

**Attitude:** Deeply private. Lunarian intimate culture is the least documented of any race — not because of repression but because Lunarian communities are tiny (~20,000 worldwide), isolated, and protective of internal customs. What is known comes from Lunarians who've lived among other races.

Sexual expression among Lunarians is intertwined with the wing-binding tradition. Wings are intimate — more intimate than nudity. A Lunarian removing their wing-bindings in another person's presence is a declaration of trust that supersedes any verbal expression. The annual Binding ceremony (communal wing-unbinding and flight) is the closest thing to a public sexual signal in Lunarian culture — the freedom of unbound flight is sensual in itself, and the night following the Binding traditionally produces the year's majority of new pairings.

**The thermal field:** Lunarian upper backs generate a low-grade thermal field — warm to the touch, faintly luminescent in total darkness. During arousal, the thermal output increases. A Lunarian whose back is glowing brighter than usual is broadcasting their state to anyone with Sight or eyes. This involuntary signal makes concealing attraction nearly impossible among Lunarians, which may contribute to the culture's emphasis on privacy — if your body advertises desire, you protect the context.

**Reproduction:** Very low fertility. One child per couple is standard. Two is rare. The Lunarian population's slow decline from 200,000 (post-genocide) to 20,000 (present) is partly attributable to this. Lunarian communities are acutely aware that every generation is smaller than the last. A Lunarian birth is celebrated with intensity disproportionate to the community's reserved nature — three days of feasting, the naming Listening, and the community's best wing-feather weavings given to the child.


### Half-Race Children

Every racial combination is biologically viable. One parent's physiology dominates (roughly 70/30 split), with the minority parent contributing subtle traits.

**Common combinations and social reception:**

| Combination | Frequency | Dominant Traits | Social Context |
|---|---|---|---|
| Human-Gorundai | Common (Caldruun) | Gorundai size/build with human features, or human build with slight tusks, greenish skin tone | Generally accepted in both communities. Gorundai clans adopt readily. |
| Human-Thalessi | Uncommon | Thalessi ears and lifespan (~150-200 years) with human adaptability, or human-presenting with extended lifespan (~120-150 years) | Class-coded. Vethara establishment disapproves quietly. Bastion Sea communities don't care. |
| Human-Khari | Common (maritime) | Khari animal traits with human build, or human-presenting with enhanced senses | Accepted in warrens. "Half-paw" is an affectionate term in canine warrens. |
| Thalessi-Morventhi | Rare (cultural barriers) | Variable — can present as either parent race | Politically loaded. Both communities scrutinize. The child belongs to whoever raised them. |
| Gorundai-Oni | Uncommon (Caldruun) | Massive. Gorundai build with Oni horn(s) and coloring, or Oni frame with tusks | Accepted in both communities. Combined strength is remarkable. |
| Khari-Rathai | Common (urban) | Small, quick, animal-featured | Nettleworks has a significant half-population. Guild membership doesn't discriminate. |
| Any-Lunarian | Very rare | Mortal-presenting with occasional Lunarian traits (faint glow, unusual eyes, extended lifespan) | Masqarat tracks these individuals. The half doesn't always know why. |

**The Thessan Precedent:** Canon Lock character Thessan Mulvar — age 23, Prime-tier King, half-Gorundai/half-Human — is the most prominent half-race individual in the current era. His existence in Vassago's inner circle normalizes mixed heritage at the highest level. His 300-meter King radius does more for half-race acceptance than any policy could.

## 9.5 Common Expressions and Sayings

#### PART A: COMMON EXPRESSIONS AND SAYINGS

The Godtide's languages share a common tongue (trade standard, derived from Thalessi diplomatic language and simplified over centuries of multiracial commerce), but the idioms, curses, and figures of speech vary by race, region, and profession. A writer who uses the right expression for the right character in the right context can communicate cultural identity in three words.

---

**Universal (Trade Standard):**
- *"Ring once."* — Good luck. Originally from the Selvaggio Departure Bell (one ring: safe journey). Now used across the world to mean "I hope this works out." Saying "ring twice" means "I expect you to come back," which carries more weight.
- *"The coat fits."* — You've earned your position. From the Wardensea storm-grey coat ceremony. Used approvingly by anyone, including people who hate the Wardensea — the idiom has transcended its origin.
- *"That's a Conqueror problem."* — Not my scale. Used when someone describes a problem too large for the speaker to solve. Delivered with a shrug. The implied second half: "and I'm not a Conqueror."
- *"Check the weight."* — Verify before you trust. From Velundri's weight-trade system, where counterfeit weights get your ship seized. Used in negotiations, intelligence assessments, and romantic contexts. "She says she loves you? Check the weight."
- *"Bounty talk."* — Empty bragging. From the gap between a Renegade's self-assessment and the MEAB's actual calculation. "He says he could take a Commandant? That's bounty talk."
- *"Gravel money."* — Small, steady income. From Brundak Kesh's method of capturing low-bounty targets by buying them drinks. "It's not glory, but it's gravel money."

**Gorundai:**
- *"Strong ground."* — Agreement. Affirmation. The Gorundai equivalent of a handshake — acknowledging that the person you're speaking to stands on solid footing. "Your plan is strong ground."
- *"Thin stone."* — An unreliable person or plan. From mining: thin stone breaks under weight. "I wouldn't follow him into a tavern. Thin stone."
- *"Blood in the tusks."* — Ready for a fight. Not a threat — a statement of readiness. A Gorundai who says this at a tavern table is announcing that the conversation has become serious enough to back up physically.
- *"Shaved."* — Insulting. Implies someone has lost their identity or heritage. Reference to tusk-shaving (cultural erasure). Using this toward a Gorundai who has actually shaved their tusks will start a fight that ends in a medical tent.

**Thalessi:**
- *"Three centuries and counting."* — Used to dismiss urgency. The Thalessi version of "calm down." Implies that the speaker has seen enough history to know that the current crisis will pass. Infuriates short-lived races.
- *"Spire-taught."* — Educated but impractical. From the Vethara Spire Academies, which produce brilliant theorists and mediocre practitioners. "She's spire-taught — give her a library and she'll conquer the world, give her a ship and she'll sink it."
- *"Read the patina."* — Look deeper. From Vethara's copper-alloy architecture, which develops patina over centuries — the surface changes but the structure endures. Used to advise patience in analysis.

**Morventhi:**
- *"Level deep."* — Serious. Genuine. From the Undersprawl's vertical geography — deeper levels are older, more fundamental, closer to the roots. "He means it. Level deep."
- *"Surface noise."* — Trivial. Meaningless. The opposite of level deep. "Don't waste my time with surface noise."
- *"Root-touched."* — Slightly mad, but in a way that might be profound. From the Third Eddan Tree's fossilized roots on Level 17, where Sight users report a heartbeat in the stone. "She's root-touched — either brilliant or insane, and the difference might not matter."

**Khari:**
- *"Path-true."* — Honest. Reliable. From the Path-singer tradition of accurate navigation. The highest compliment a Khari can give a non-Khari: "You're path-true."
- *"Crossed scent."* — Conflicting information. From the vulpine and lupine practice of tracking by smell — crossed scents mean multiple truths in the same space. "I'm getting crossed scent on this deal."
- *"Warren-close."* — Intimate. Tight-knit. From the warren social structure. "That crew is warren-close. Don't try to split them."

**Rathai:**
- *"Built it, didn't name it."* — The Rathai summary of their position in the world. Used when someone else takes credit for Rathai work. Delivered with varying degrees of bitterness depending on context.
- *"Tinthread fast."* — Quick and functional. From the Nettleworks' Tinthread sub-district, where Grimoire components are assembled at speed. "I need this done Tinthread fast — ugly is fine, broken is not."
- *"Up twelve."* — Moving up in the world. From the Nettleworks' twelve levels — each level up is closer to the surface, closer to sunlight, closer to Thalveris proper. "She got a commission on the Kingsrun. She's going up twelve."

**Oni:**
- *"Kamiuchi."* — God-drumming. Lightning striking the same peak for hours. Used to describe sustained, unavoidable pressure. "The Wardensea's been hitting us kamiuchi for a month."
- *"Storm-calm."* — The eye of the hurricane. Deceptive peace. "Don't trust the quiet. That's storm-calm."
- *"Thunder's child."* — Someone born into conflict. Not pejorative — Oni consider conflict natural. "She's thunder's child — she won't know what to do with peace."

**Wardensea-Specific:**
- *"Taking the grey."* — Earning officer rank in the Wardensea. Used as shorthand for any significant transition. "He took the grey in two years. Fast track."
- *"Coat weather."* — Trouble coming. From the superstition that storms follow newly-earned storm-grey coats. "Check the horizon. Feels like coat weather."
- *"Gyre-touched."* — Haunted. Psychologically damaged. From Third Division's perimeter service near the Gyre. Used across the Wardensea to describe anyone who's been through too much. "Don't push him. He's gyre-touched."

**Kingsrun-Specific:**
- *"Past Ossengaard."* — Proven. Vetted. Survived scrutiny. "She's past Ossengaard — you can trust her manifest."
- *"Shoalfolk owe."* — A debt that will be collected unexpectedly. "Don't accept favors from strangers. Shoalfolk owe."
- *"Vael's light."* — The point of no return. Used for any irrevocable commitment. "She signed the Venture Line. She's past Vael's light."
- *"Dark water."* — The unknown. Senmovar's territory. Used for any situation where information is absent and danger is present. "I don't know what's in that contract. Dark water."


## 9.6 Food Culture

#### PART B: FOOD CULTURE

Food in the Godtide is regional, practical, and revealing. What a person eats tells you where they're from, what they can afford, and how far they are from home. A writer who knows the food knows the world.

---

**Thalveris (Capital):**
The capital eats well and diversely. Kassevan Harbor's eastern quay brings fish, grain, and imported goods from across Orenthas. Street food is cheap and multiracial: Gorundai skewered meat stalls next to Rathai noodle carts next to Thalessi pastry shops. The Pillar District eats differently — formal dining, Thalessi cuisine (subtle, complex, portion-controlled), served on bronze plates that match the city's patina. Verossa Heights eats Thalessi food and pretends it doesn't enjoy the Nettleworks street vendors who operate on the border between uphill and downhill. The Nettleworks eats whatever's cheap: tunnel-grown mushrooms, geothermally-steamed root vegetables, salt-cured fish bought in bulk from the harbor, and *chalkbread* — a dense, pale flatbread baked on the heated stone of the upper tunnel walls, filling rather than flavorful, and the first thing any Nettleworks-born person asks for when they return home. Suuba Mettani can eat anything the Kingsrun provides without complaint. She has been seen eating Pellune Voss's smoked eel with her eyes closed and an expression that her crew interprets as religious ecstasy and Khellen interprets as homesickness.

**Gorundai Territories:**
Gorundai food is heavy, meat-dominant, and designed to fuel bodies that are larger and more metabolically demanding than any other race. Stews are the foundation: slow-cooked in iron pots over open fires (or volcanic vents, in Brannach), with root vegetables, grain dumplings, and whatever meat is available. *Rageshed stew* (named after the holdout clan, adopted by the Confederation) uses smoked boar, black turnip, and a fermented grain paste that smells appalling and tastes complex enough to justify the smell. Gorundai feasting culture is communal — the pot goes in the center, bowls are filled in order of age (elders first), and refusing a second serving is interpreted as dissatisfaction with the cook. Desserts exist but are considered frivolous; the closest equivalent is *ashcake* — a sweetened grain patty cooked in coals, charred on the outside, soft in the center, eaten with honey when available and plain when not.

**Kingsrun Food:**
Ship food on the Kingsrun follows a predictable arc: good at Selvaggio, declining through the mid-route, desperate by the deep zone, and whatever's available past Korrentide. The staples are hardtack (flour-and-water biscuit baked twice for preservation, edible for months, enjoyable for approximately none of those months), salt-cured fish (protein that travels, purchased in bulk at every stop), dried citrus (scurvy prevention, worth its weight in Silver Spans by mid-route), and *dock stew* — whatever's in the pot today, cooked by whoever drew galley duty, judged by no standard except "is it hot" and "will it kill me."

The cooks who transcend dock stew become legends. Pellune Voss (Deshanni Reapers) makes smoked eel that crews at adjacent docks have offered to pay for. Lessen Garval (Gannet Crew) stumbled into Grimoire fame through his reef-kelp stew, filmed by Tuuma as background content, now replicated on forty thousand ships (none correctly — Lessen won't share the secret, which is a particular species of kelp harvested only at Merrenbach's low-tide pools, salted differently than mainland kelp, and impossible to find outside a three-island radius). Brenn Khorast (Vassago's Fleet) serves salt-crust reef fish every seventh night regardless of combat conditions, and the recipe — which he learned from Vassago, who learned it from his mother — is the Fleet's unofficial anthem, more unifying than any speech.

**Kelvanni Cuisine:**
Ourseva Denn's clinic feeds patients from the island's micro-forest of medicinal plants, and the food is simultaneously medicine and meal. *Recovery broth* is a thin, herb-heavy soup that tastes like a garden that someone has been crying into — earthy, slightly bitter, unexpectedly comforting. Patients who complain about the taste are told by the medical staff that the bitterness is therapeutic. This is true. It is also the medical staff's way of ending the conversation. Crews who've been treated at Kelvanni develop a specific nostalgia for the broth: it doesn't taste good, but it tastes like the moment they stopped bleeding, and the association is powerful enough to override the palate.

**Drink Culture:**
*Storm tea* (Oni): Highland herbs steeped in water heated by volcanic vents, served scalding in stone cups. Bitter, astringent, and culturally sacred — the challenge toast at Sennaku Gate is conducted with storm tea. Kuldhara drinks it constantly. Her crew drinks it because she does. Non-Oni who try it describe the experience as "drinking a thunderstorm that someone has apologized for but not sweetened."

*Gorundai stout* (Gorundai): Black, thick, with a flavor profile that transitions from coffee to mineral to regret. Brewed in the Ironmarrow Coast mining towns, where the water table's mineral content produces a beer that non-Gorundai describe as "aggressively acquired taste." Gorundai stout is the Signal Branch's quarterly prize for top analyst — the current champion chose it; no one else can finish a glass.

*Reef rum* (Kingsrun): Produced at Selvaggio from sugarcane imported through Goltieri's supply chains, fermented in copper stills, and distributed across the first half of the Kingsrun. The quality ranges from genuinely pleasant (Departure Row's premium bars) to borderline toxic (anything sold from an unlabeled bottle at a Shoalfield raft-town platform). Reef rum is the Kingsrun's social lubricant, its negotiation tool, and its anesthetic. Brundak Kesh — the bounty hunter who captures targets by buying them drinks — uses reef rum exclusively. "The cheap stuff works faster."

*Vethara wine* (Thalessi): Grown in the terraced vineyards outside Vethara's walls, aged in copper-lined cellars, and served with the ceremonial gravity of a people who have had three centuries to perfect a single vintage. A good Vethara wine costs more than most sailors earn in a month. Dessaren Goltieri built his wine cellar over eleven years specifically to host the dinner with Kuorren. The wine was real. Everything else at the table was negotiation.


## 9.7 Entertainment

#### PART C: ENTERTAINMENT

---

**Bones (The Universal Game):**
The dice game *bones* is played on every Renegade ship, in every Kingsrun tavern, and at every Wardensea garrison where officers pretend not to notice. The rules are simple: three bone dice (carved from whale vertebrae, fish spine, or actual bone — the material is traditional, not functional), roll for combinations, bet on outcomes. The simplicity is the problem: every ship has a slightly different version of the rules, adapted over years of isolated play. Cross-crew games at port produce rule disputes that escalate from debate to shouting to fistfights to drinking together to playing another round with different rules that produce new disputes. The longest recorded bones argument (nine hours, a Wardensea Lieutenant and a bounty hunter who were technically supposed to be trying to arrest each other) is famous not for its length but for its resolution: the bounty hunter won, the Lieutenant paid up, and then the Lieutenant attempted the arrest. The bounty hunter escaped during the confusion of counting change.

**Grimoire Culture:**
The Grimoire network has replaced the town square, the theater, the newspaper, and the gossip network simultaneously. The Black-band — the illegal frequency where Renegade culture lives — is the world's primary entertainment platform, and its content categories tell you everything about what the world values:

*Combat footage* (most popular): Raw clips, phonk edits, analysis breakdowns. Gorune Vassik's phonk edit of Kuldhara's Awakening (900 million views) is the most-watched piece of content in history. Combat footage functions as entertainment, tactical education, and recruitment material simultaneously.

*Bounty analysis* (second most popular): Drussara Kenn's reverse-engineering of MEAB calculations, real-time bounty tracking, speculation about upcoming adjustments. When a Renegade's bounty increases, the announcement is an event — crews celebrate, viewers debate, and the Grimoire ecosystem treats it the way financial markets treat earnings reports. The bounty poster is the Godtide's celebrity headshot, and SK's faceless 6.42 billion poster is the most recognizable image in the world.

*Ship food channels* (third most popular, surprisingly): Cooking content from Renegade ships. Lessen Garval's accidental fame (reef-kelp stew, forty thousand replications, none correct) exemplifies the genre — food made under impossible conditions, judged by people who've been eating hardtack for months, and elevated to art by the contrast between the setting and the skill. Three Grimoire food critics have rated Lessen's sulfur-salt dried fish as "the best thing produced by a Renegade crew, and yes that includes the combat."

*Fan pairings* (niche but intense): Dossen Trell's "Chemistry Report" has six million followers analyzing potential romantic relationships between Renegade captains who have never met. BullFox (Tomoe/Mavrokka) has twelve thousand pieces of fan art. The genre is treated as investigative journalism by fans and as a security concern by intelligence officers. Tuuma Kessav has liked seven BullFox posts. Tomoe doesn't know. When she finds out, someone is getting thrown overboard.

*Power rankings* (2,000 active channels, none agreeing): The Black-band's most argumentative genre. Rankings updated after every fight, clip, or rumor. Arguments are vicious, passionate, and grounded in sophisticated understanding of Dominion mechanics combined with unsophisticated understanding of how fights actually work. "The Absolute List" (14 million followers) once ranked a Rathai engineer above a Wardensea Commandant for "technical creativity in enclosed spaces." This crashed two relay stations.

**Tavern Entertainment:**
Kingsrun taverns offer the entertainment the Grimoire can't: physical presence, face-to-face interaction, and the specific electricity of being in a room full of people who might kill each other and are instead playing bones. Selvaggio's Departure Row has twelve taverns, each with its own character: the Crossed Anchor (Delvessa Ghal's establishment, oldest on the Row, where the ledger of departures and returns is kept behind the bar), the Burning Coin (Goltieri-affiliated, better rum, Bureau agents at every table pretending to be sailors), and the Clinker (Rathai-owned, smallest, loudest, where Smalls once won a bones tournament against sailors twice his height and has not stopped talking about it).

Live music exists but is unsystematic — a Morventhi echo-singer in a Kethrun tavern, a Khari path-singer performing fragments at a Merrenbach dock, an Oni drummer at a Brannach feast who doesn't realize the rhythm he's keeping is King-adjacent and is inadvertently making everyone in the room feel braver. Music is not a profession in the Godtide. It's a side effect of culture — the sounds that communities make when they're not trying to make music, compressed into traditions that are passed down because they work rather than because they're beautiful.


## 9.8 Technology Texture

#### PART D: TECHNOLOGY TEXTURE

---

**The Grimoire Device:**
Palm-sized. Stone casing. The Godtide's phone, radio, television, and banking terminal combined into an object that costs three Silver Spans at the low end and looks like a carved rock. The Varrek designed the protocol. The Rathai build eighty percent of them in Tinthread. The standard model (limestone casing, two-year lifespan) is the most common manufactured object in the world — more ubiquitous than coins, more relied-upon than weapons, and the single most important technology in daily life.

A person's Grimoire tells you about them. Limestone standard: civilian, working-class, functional. Basalt premium: someone with money or connections. Obsidian custom (Undersprawl-carved, bioluminescent inlay): Morventhi, old money, or someone trying to look like both. Military-grade (Gannavar encrypted): Wardensea, Tidewatch, or stolen. Modified (visible solder, jury-rigged antenna, Tinthread repair marks): Renegade, Nettleworks-born, or an engineer who can't stop improving things. Suuba Mettani's Grimoire has been modified so many times it barely resembles the original device — Kellen Truss has added a signal booster, a directional broadcast antenna, and a waterproofing seal made from reef-coral resin. The modifications are technically illegal (unlicensed Grimoire alteration). Khellen considers this a feature.

**Resonance Weapons:**
Weapons forged to channel, amplify, or redirect Dominion energy. The Godtide's technology of violence, produced in the Kethrun Undersprawl's Forge Quarter and sold at Ossavar's open market. Three grades: Craft (functional, mass-produced, affordable), Master (individual commissions, superior materials, named by the smith), and Named (unique, storied, with properties that seem to exceed their physical construction). Named-grade weapons are cultural artifacts — Hessen Malcourt's Bellstrike, Grielle Tossk's Needlepoint, Draven Hossk's Greytooth — and the smiths who produce them are celebrities in the Undersprawl.

The experience of holding a Resonance weapon: it hums. Not audibly, not always — but a Dominion user who grips a properly forged weapon feels a resonance in the metal that synchronizes with their own energy output. A well-matched weapon feels like an extension of the hand. A poorly matched weapon feels like holding someone else's argument — the energy flows, but wrong, and the dissonance produces headaches and reduced performance. Finding the right Resonance weapon is a process that Renegade fighters take as seriously as choosing a crew. The weapon doesn't choose you (that's fiction), but the wrong weapon will let you know.

**Ships:**
Wooden hulls, canvas sails, and the engineering ingenuity of a world that has magic and hasn't figured out engines. Ships in the Godtide are built for a specific set of conditions: ocean travel under wind and current, with occasional exposure to Dominion combat (which means the hull needs to withstand forces that no terrestrial shipwright would design for). Standard materials: timber (Verossian Range, harvested and aged for Wardensea contracts), copper-alloy fittings (Gannavar-sourced, Varrek-engineered), canvas sails (Orenthan cotton, woven in Hessavar's mills). Exceptional ships use Undersprawl vethrstone reinforcement, Kethrun-forged hardware, and Brannach volcanic ore in their keels.

The relationship between crew and ship is intimate in a way that non-sailors don't understand. Dussa Kerven talks to the Regrade because the Regrade has been sailing for thirty-nine years and has absorbed, in the grain of its timber and the shape of its repairs, the history of everyone who's stood at its helm. Drossen Kethvaine of the Undertow extends his Iron through the hull and feels his ship as his own body. Koddrun Achtavaan of the SK crew navigated the Vossdren by touch — Iron through the wheel into the hull, feeling the keel the way a Sight user feels a room. A ship is not a vehicle. A ship is a partner.

---

## 9.9 Money Texture

#### PART E: MONEY TEXTURE — What Commerce Feels Like

---

**The Currency in Hand:**
A Copper Bit is a small, warm-colored coin that feels lighter than it should — the alloy is copper-dominant but not pure, and the wear pattern on a well-circulated Bit produces a smooth, almost oily surface. Street vendors accept Bits for everything: a skewer of grilled meat (2-3 Bits), a bowl of dock stew (1 Bit), a cup of reef rum (5 Bits at a Departure Row tavern, 1 Bit at a Shoalfield raft-town). A Silver Span is heavier — a rectangular coin with a notched edge, designed to be broken into halves and quarters for smaller transactions (the notches are stress lines, and a sailor with strong hands can snap a Span into four pieces, each worth 25 Bits). A Gold Sovereign is something most people never touch: heavy, warm-toned, stamped with the Masqarat seal on one face and a blank space on the other where the sovereign's portrait would go if anyone knew what the sovereign looked like. The blank face is unsettling. It's the most common reminder in daily life that the world's highest authority is a mystery.

Kolmari Notes are paper — thick, watermarked, Grimoire-verified through an embedded rune circuit that authenticates the note when scanned by any Kolmari terminal. A crumpled Kolmari Note in a sailor's pocket represents wealth that exists only because the Confederation says it does, backed by a treasury that funds both the Wardensea that hunts Renegades and the Venture Lines that finance them. Holding a Kolmari Note is holding a contradiction: the paper that makes the world's economy function is issued by an institution that profits from both sides of the world's central conflict.

Grimoire Credit is invisible — a number on a Kolmari account, accessible from any Grimoire terminal at any affiliated post. The wealthy and the institutional operate in credit. The poor and the Renegade operate in coin. The transition from coin to credit — the moment a Renegade crew opens a Kolmari account, accepts a Venture Line, begins operating within the Confederation's financial architecture — is the moment freedom acquires a price tag. The Venture Line charges 15-40% of all voyage revenue. Most aspiring Renegades are broke. The Kolmari don't need an army. They have interest rates.

**What Things Cost (for scale):**
A night in a Selvaggio tavern room: 5 Silver Spans (cheap room, shared floor), 2 Gold Sovereigns (private room above Departure Row, Goltieri-adjacent, probably bugged). A full ship outfitting for a Kingsrun attempt: 2-8 million Sovereigns, which is why Venture Lines exist and why most crews start in debt. A Wardensea Lieutenant's annual salary: roughly 50 Gold Sovereigns (500,000 Bits, enough to live comfortably in Thalveris, not enough to live in Verossa Heights). A Kolmari Note worth 1,000 Sovereigns: sufficient to buy a small fishing vessel, or to pay a Shoalfield pilot, or to settle a Durromakh toll for a medium-sized ship. The most expensive thing in the world that isn't a God Fruit: a Throssmund-built ship (seven-year waiting list, price by negotiation only, starting around 10 million Sovereigns for a standard hull). The Vossdren was built there. Seven-year wait, paid for by a man who was twenty-five and already the most wanted person alive.

**Quick-Reference Price Table:**

| Meat skewer (street food) | 2-3 Bits | Gorundai portions cost double |

---

**The Black Economy:**
Beneath the Kolmari's orderly financial architecture runs a parallel economy of barter, debt, and unwritten obligation. The Kingsrun operates on this economy more than the formal one. A favor owed at Kelvanni. A Tide Debt at the Shoalfields. A slag gift accepted at Brannach. A pass token earned at Durromakh. These obligations have no Kolmari value — they cannot be deposited, traded, or liquidated. They are worth more than money because they represent something money cannot buy: proof that you showed up, paid attention, and were considered worth trusting.

The Nettleworks runs the world's largest informal economy. Twelve levels of tunnel district, 1.8 million people, and a financial system that the Kolmari's Ledger Agents have spent decades trying to map and have never fully penetrated. Rathai barter networks — goods exchanged for goods, services for services, debts recorded in notebooks and memories rather than Grimoire accounts — operate below the Confederation's visibility threshold. A Tinthread assembly worker who needs medical care doesn't visit a licensed physician (too expensive) — she visits the woman three tunnels down who was a physician before the licensing fees priced her out, and pays in repaired Grimoire components. The Nettleworks economy is invisible to the Masqarat, invisible to the Kolmari, and sustaining 1.8 million people who the formal economy has decided aren't worth the infrastructure.

**Bounty as Currency:**
A Renegade's bounty is not just a price on their head — it's a credit rating, a rÃ©sumÃ©, and a social status indicator compressed into a single number. A crew captain with a bounty under 50 million has difficulty recruiting (not famous enough to attract talent). A captain between 50 and 200 million is taken seriously. Between 200 million and a billion: Commandant response, dedicated Wardensea tracking, and the respect of every Kingsrun tavern. Above a billion: you're not a pirate anymore, you're a political entity, and the Grimoire ecosystem treats your bounty adjustments the way investors treat quarterly earnings.

When a bounty increases, the crew celebrates. They toast the new poster. They update their Grimoire profiles. The number is worn like a rank — higher bounty means higher danger, higher danger means higher credibility, and higher credibility means better deals at every port. The perversity of this system — that the institution trying to catch you is also providing your marketing — is understood by everyone and discussed by no one, because the system works for both sides. The Masqarat gets a threat-ranking system. The Renegades get a reputation engine. The Kolmari finance both and profit from the spread.


## 9.10 Weather, Seasons, and the Shape of a Year

#### PART F: WEATHER, SEASONS, AND THE SHAPE OF A YEAR

---

The Godtide's calendar is Masqarat-standard: twelve months, four seasons, Year 5,590 (current). The seasons matter because the Kingsrun is seasonal — the sailing window opens in spring and closes in late autumn, and the weather between those endpoints determines who lives and who doesn't.

**Spring (Months 1-3):** The Kingsrun season begins. Crews that wintered in Selvaggio, Thalveris, or Bastion Sea ports begin departures. Weather is mild in the early stops, unpredictable in the mid-route. Recruitment peaks. Departure Row is crowded, loud, and optimistic. The betting board outside the Crossed Anchor opens for the season, and the first bets are placed with the cheerful recklessness of people who haven't buried anyone yet.

**Summer (Months 4-6):** Peak traffic. The Kingsrun is at its most populated and most dangerous — more ships means more encounters, more competition for resources at stops, and more Wardensea patrols. Ossengaard processes three times its winter volume. Kelvanni overflows. Velundri's market is shoulder-to-shoulder. The weather is hot, the doldrums are common (the long open stretch between Kelvanni and Velundri is worst in midsummer — windless days that turn a four-day transit into ten), and the sea creatures are active.

**Autumn (Months 7-9):** The window narrows. Storms increase on the mid-Kingsrun. Experienced crews push through. Rookie crews start turning back. The deep zone (Kassuran Spire to the Threshold) is navigable but increasingly hostile — the storms that are dramatic in summer become dangerous in autumn. Korrentide's retired Undertow watch the weather and shake their heads. Vael's Lantern sees its highest turnback rate.

**Winter (Months 10-12):** The Kingsrun is functionally closed. The weather between Ossengaard and Kassuran Spire makes passage inadvisable, and the deep zone is effectively impossible for non-Conqueror ships. The few crews still on the route are either committed (past the point of return) or stranded (waiting at a stop for spring). Selvaggio goes quiet. The betting board closes. Delvessa Ghal reviews her ledger, notes which crews haven't been heard from, and adds the silence to the right column.


## 9.11 Smells, Sounds, and Sensory Anchors

#### PART G: SMELLS, SOUNDS, AND SENSORY ANCHORS

---

A short reference for writers — the sensory details that place a reader instantly in a location without needing a paragraph of description.

**Selvaggio:** Woodsmoke, frying oil, rum, Gambit Fruit residue (chemical, headache-adjacent). The Departure Bell's tone — deeper now, with a buzz from the crack.

**The Nettleworks:** Solder flux, heated stone, bioluminescent fungi (faintly sweet), the constant low vibration of Grimoire manufacturing from Tinthread.

**Kethrun Undersprawl:** Wet stone, geothermal mineral tang, the echo of footsteps in vertical shafts, bioluminescent blue-green light that makes everything look submerged.

**A Wardensea ship:** Salt, fresh paint (the storm-grey coat culture extends to the hulls — Wardensea vessels are maintained obsessively), metal polish, and the specific ozone smell of high-tier Iron use during drills.

**A Renegade ship:** Salt, tar, cooking smoke, unwashed crew, and the particular wood-and-oil smell of a hull that's been at sea for months without a dry-dock visit. Every Renegade ship smells slightly different because every ship's cook uses different spices.

**Brannach:** Sulfur. Mineral char from volcanic-vent cooking. Hot stone. The particular metallic smell of fresh-forged Brannach ore.

**Kelvanni:** Herbs. Antiseptic. The flowering hedge Ourseva planted forty years ago — sweet, persistent, and specifically designed to overpower the smell of blood.

**Sennaku Highlands:** Ozone from constant lightning discharge. Volcanic soil (rich, dark, wet). Storm tea steeping in stone cups. Singed fabric — Kuldhara runs hot enough that proximity smells like standing near a fire.

**The Deep Kingsrun (past Kassuran Spire):** Cold metal (the water temperature drops and the humidity condenses on iron fittings). Bioluminescent organisms produce a faint organic sweetness. The absence of familiar sounds — no seabirds past Vossgrave, no fish breaking the surface past Korrentide, nothing but hull and water and the silence that isn't empty.

**The Threshold:** Nothing. The water absorbs smell the way it absorbs light. The Grimoire is dead. The wind carries no information. The absence of sensory input is itself a sensation — the feeling of standing in a space that has been cleaned of everything except the choice.


## 9.12 THE GRIMOIRE — The World's Nervous System [NEW]

### What It Is
A pocket-sized runestone device. Varrek-designed communication protocol, Rathai-manufactured hardware, global network coverage on Orenthas and Caldruun (patchy to nonexistent in the Sundren). Functions as: phone, social media platform, news source, bounty tracker, and the entire discourse ecosystem.

### What It Feels Like
The Grimoire is warm. Not metaphorically — the runestone core generates low-level heat during active transmission. Experienced users recognize the warmth gradient: barely noticeable during passive reception, distinctly warm during active sending, and uncomfortably hot during high-bandwidth operations (streaming live combat footage, downloading Wardensea bulletin updates during a crisis). A Grimoire that's cool to the touch is either off, broken, or out of range — and in the modern era, out of range means you're either in the Sundren, in the deep Kingsrun past Kassuran Spire, or dead.

The display is not a screen. It's a runic projection — light generated by the stone's surface, readable in direct sunlight, adjustable in brightness by pressure (squeeze harder = brighter). Text appears as formed runes that resolve into the user's native script. Images are low-resolution by modern Earth standards but high enough for bounty poster identification. Video exists but is bandwidth-heavy — live streams of Conqueror fights regularly crash local relay infrastructure.

### The Grimoire Ecosystem [NEW]

**Bounty Tracking:** The Masqarat's official bounty updates push to all Grimoires within seconds. A bounty increase triggers a notification cascade: the target's face, the new number, the issuing authority. Renegade crews celebrate increases. The Grimoire is the mechanism by which "bounty as credit rating" actually functions — everyone knows your number because everyone's Grimoire told them.

**The Discourse:** Forty billion users arguing about everything. Grimoire "channels" are topic-sorted information streams — some official (Masqarat bulletins, Wardensea patrol advisories), most unofficial (crew rankings, fight speculation, Conqueror sightings, conspiracy theories about the Second Age). The discourse moves fast. A Conqueror sighting in the southern Kingsrun is global news within minutes. A Renegade crew's defeat is public humiliation within the hour. Privacy in the Grimoire age is an illusion that some people maintain more successfully than others.

**Grimoire Culture:** The device has produced its own social behaviors:
- **The Refresh:** Checking your bounty number. Renegades do this the way people check their phones — compulsively, especially after a fight or a notable event. "Did it go up?" is the Renegade equivalent of checking your likes.
- **The Screenshot:** Grimoire captures of notable moments, shared virally. A particularly dramatic bounty poster. A freeze-frame of a Conqueror clash. Wardensea officers caught doing something embarrassing. Screenshots are currency in Grimoire discourse.
- **Phonk Edits:** Short, stylized Grimoire clips set to music, celebrating Renegade or Conqueror moments. The editing style originated in Selvaggio's Departure Row culture and spread globally. Conquerors get the best edits. A really good phonk edit can increase a Renegade's recruitment by measurable percentages.
- **The Dead Channel:** When a Grimoire stops transmitting, the network flags it. A crew's Grimoires all going dark simultaneously is how the world learns they've been lost at sea. The Kingsrun's attrition rate is measured in Dead Channel reports.

**Network Limitations:**
- Coverage requires relay towers. Cities have dense coverage. Open ocean has relay buoys along major shipping routes. The deep Kingsrun has gaps. The Sundren has almost nothing.
- The Vorrenmaw is a dead zone. No Grimoire has ever transmitted from inside the Clutch. The Sovereign King's Grimoire went dark at the perimeter.
- Mettavuur cannot read individual Grimoire communications (the network is too vast), but the Pillar of Silence can flag keywords and track transmission patterns. Encrypted communication exists but requires Varrek technical skill to implement.

### Grimoire Network Technical Architecture

### Grimoire Technical Architecture

**The device:** Palm-sized runestone (~8Ã—14Ã—2cm). Carved stone casing (limestone cheap, basalt premium). Interior: micro-carved rune lattice — processor and antenna in one. Designed by **Varrek** (Verath Standard protocol). Built by **Rathai** (80% assembled in Tinthread, Nettleworks). Standard cost: 3 Silver Spans (~2 year lifespan). Premium: 2-5 Gold Sovereigns (decades).

**Signal propagation:** Frequency-modulated runestone resonance through ambient Dominion — functionally instantaneous to ~3,000 miles. Beyond that: relay stations (14 on Merchant Spine, 6 on Kingsrun, 11 on Caldruun coast, 0 on Sundren). High-output Dominion disrupts signals — Conqueror-tier King knocks out Grimoires island-wide.

**Frequency Bands:**

| Band | Use | Access |
|---|---|---|
| Red | Emergency/distress | Public (false emergencies = criminal) |
| White | Official Masqarat communications | Restricted |
| Grey | Wardensea military | Encrypted (quarterly update) |
| Blue | Commercial/Kolmari banking | Licensed |
| Green | Civilian messaging | Open (~200 mi range) |
| Gold | Large-scale broadcast | Licensed (expensive) |
| Black | Everything the Masqarat doesn't want on the others | Illegal. Enforcement selective. Where Renegade culture lives. |

**Signal Branch** (Pillar of Silence): Can flood frequencies, intercept specific devices within ~500m, issue content suppression orders (147 in past 5 years). **Sundren Intercept:** All Sundren signals auto-routed through filter station, 30-90 second delay, auto-screening for interior phenomena references.

### Bounty Hunters — The Profession

No guild. No certification. No training. Four types: freelancers (30% success rate, 15% mortality), hunting crews (3-8 members, ~50% success), Wardensea bounty details (10-15% commission), Anointed hunters (institutional obligation).

**Bounty culture at street level:** Posters are art. SK's faceless 6.42B poster = most recognizable image in the world. Bounty reveals are events — Grimoire ecosystem treats them like stock earnings. When a Renegade's bounty increases, their crew celebrates and toasts the new poster. The hunter's valuation becomes the prey's credential.

### Grimoire Culture — The Digital Discourse


---

### Power-Scaling Culture

The Godtide has forty billion Grimoire users, and approximately thirty-nine billion of them have opinions about who would win in a fight. The power-scaling community — concentrated on Black-band channels, visible across all bands during major bounty announcements — operates with the rigor of academic scholarship and the objectivity of a bar fight.

**The Tiers Argument.** The foundational debate: does Dominion tier or God Fruit ability determine a fight's outcome? This argument has been running since Grimoire technology made high-level combat visible to civilians, and it has never been resolved, and it will never be resolved, because both sides are partially correct and neither side will admit this. The Iron-Supremacist position ("Raw Dominion tier decides everything; God Fruits are a crutch") and the Fruit-Superiority position ("A creative God Fruit user beats a higher-tier Dominion user every time") each have their patron analysts, their canonical examples, and their irreconcilable interpretive frameworks. The argument has its own Black-band channel. The channel has 90 million subscribers. The moderators have given up moderating.

**The Analysts.** Named commentators with followings large enough to move Grimoire discourse:

- **Gorune Vassik** (referenced in the bible — the Grimoire combat analyst with 900 million views on the Kuldhara Awakening edit) runs a channel called *Deadweight Analysis*. His approach: raw data, fight footage frame-by-frame, Dominion output calculations using a formula he developed and refuses to share. His rankings are respected because they're methodical. His rankings are wrong about thirty percent of the time because Dominion doesn't work like math. He does not acknowledge the thirty percent.
- **Hollenne Tavk** (Khari/feline, 52) runs *Reef Watch*, a channel dedicated to Kingsrun combat analysis. She has never left Selvaggio. Her analysis is based entirely on footage and secondhand accounts. She is inexplicably accurate. Three Conqueror lieutenants follow her channel. She does not know this.
- **Dross Kellam** (Rathai, 27) runs *Scale Check*, a meme-format channel that posts power rankings as absurdist comedy. Sample ranking: "TOP 5 STRONGEST ON THE KINGSRUN: 5. Kuldhara's storm. 4. Kuldhara's crew. 3. Kuldhara. 2. Kuldhara's opinion about marinades. 1. Kassara Vellun's pricing formula." Scale Check has 120 million subscribers. Serious analysts hate it. Serious analysts also follow it, because Dross's joke rankings are often more predictive than the serious ones, and this fact is the power-scaling community's most uncomfortable open secret.

**Regional Bias.** Orenthas-based analysts favor Iron-dominant fighters because Orenthas's Wardensea culture values Iron mastery. Caldruun-based analysts favor Sight specialists because Caldruun's volcanic terrain makes Sight more useful than Iron for threat detection. Bastion Sea analysts favor God Fruit users because the Sea's naval culture prizes unique abilities over raw Dominion output. Nobody acknowledges these biases. Everyone perceives them in others. The phrase "typical Orenthas desk" is an insult in Caldruun analysis circles. The phrase "Caldruun copium" is an insult in Orenthas circles. The phrases have equivalent weight and identical accuracy.

---

### Bounty Culture

The bounty system is a Masqarat threat assessment tool that became a popularity metric by accident and can never go back. A bounty number measures threat to institutional order. The public treats it as a scorecard.

**Bounty Complaints.** Characters have opinions about their bounties that have nothing to do with threat assessment:

- Tomoe Gallacs's bounty is 320 million Sovereigns. Mavrokka Deshaan's is 410 million. Tomoe has not commented on this discrepancy publicly. Privately — according to Lessen Garval, who overhears everything from the galley — Tomoe once said: "She destroyed ONE harbor. I stole a Wardensea intelligence archive." Lessen's editorial: "The captain is competitive about exactly one thing, and it's the one thing she pretends she doesn't care about."
- Ressaven Delvun's bounty is 460 million. He knows the exact formula that would produce this number based on his Wardensea incident reports, threat assessments, and property damage estimates. He has run the calculation. The actual number should be 473.2 million. The discrepancy of 13.2 million bothers him more than the bounty itself.
- Calmund Vosst's bounty has gone DOWN once. From 340 million to 310 million, after a Masqarat bureaucratic error reclassified one of his incidents as "property damage" rather than "assault on government infrastructure." The reclassification was corrected within a week, but the temporary decrease was broadcast, and Calmund received condolence messages from three other Cursed Generation captains. He found this humiliating. His bounty is now 380 million, and he has not discussed the decrease since.
- One Anointed Seven member — Grielle Tossk — had her bounty frozen at 780 million upon recruitment. Her response to the freeze, delivered during the signing ceremony: "You're paying me less than I'm worth. I expect a correction when I resign."

**The Secondary Market.** Bounty-change betting is technically illegal under Masqarat financial regulations. The market operates anyway, managed through Black-band Grimoire channels with encrypted wagering systems designed by Varrek bookmakers. Common bets: "Will X's bounty increase this quarter?" "Which Cursed Generation captain gets the next raise?" "Will the Wardensea issue a new Conqueror-level bounty this year?" The largest bet ever placed: 200,000 Gold Sovereigns on whether Vassago Moren's bounty would exceed 6 billion by year's end. (It did not. The bettor — identity unknown — reportedly said: "Vassago isn't trying hard enough.")

**"First."** Every bounty announcement broadcast on the Broadwave — every single one, without exception, for the past eleven years — has received a comment reading "first" within the first three seconds of broadcast. The commenter's identity is unknown. The Broadwave's technical team has attempted to block the account. The account reappears. The "first" commenter is the Grimoire's oldest running mystery and its most reliable phenomenon. Conspiracy theories range from "it's a Varrek-designed automated program" to "it's Senmovar, and this is how he communicates with the outside world." (The second theory has 4 million subscribers. It is almost certainly wrong. The "almost" is what keeps the thread alive.)

---

### Comment Section Culture

Grimoire comment sections are the Godtide's marketplace of bad takes, sincere enthusiasm, and the specific madness that occurs when forty billion people can talk to each other simultaneously about things that excite them.

**Running Arguments:**
- "Iron vs. Sight — which is the better expression?" has been running for fourteen years. Neither side has won. Neither side will win. The argument is self-sustaining because every major fight produces evidence for both positions, and the interpretive framework is flexible enough that any outcome can be claimed by either camp. A Sight user beating an Iron user proves Sight is better. An Iron user beating a Sight user proves Iron is better. A draw proves both positions simultaneously. The argument is the content. The answer is beside the point.
- "Could Vassago beat Daeshara?" is the Conqueror-tier version, and it has the additional complication that both Conquerors are alive and could theoretically settle it. They haven't. The fact that they haven't is itself analyzed for clues. "Vassago won't fight Daeshara because he knows he'd lose" (Daeshara fans). "Vassago won't fight Daeshara because the collateral damage isn't worth it" (Vassago fans). "They haven't fought because they're friends and this is a stupid question" (the position nobody wants because it's boring and probably correct).

**Fan Communities:**
- **Stormchasers** (Kuldhara fans): Produce phonk edits of her lightning footage. Run analysis channels focused on Raiju Fruit mechanics. Host an annual "Storm Day" event where fans gather at coastal locations during thunderstorms and drink storm tea. Attendance has reached 50,000. The Wardensea monitors these gatherings but has not intervened because technically it's just weather enthusiasts drinking tea.
- **The Bureau** (Goltieri fans): An ironic fan community that styles itself after Goltieri's Montalvo Bureau. Members address each other as "Agent." They produce analysis content with the aesthetic of intelligence briefings. The content is surprisingly good. Goltieri is reportedly aware of the fan community and has never commented, which the fans interpret as approval, because in Goltieri's communication style, silence IS approval (silence is also disapproval, and also indifference, which is why interpreting Goltieri is the fan community's primary hobby).
- **The Mud Pit** (Mavrokka fans): Named for Mavrokka's fighting style — direct, messy, and impossible to ignore. The Mud Pit produces combat highlight reels set to Gorundai war-chanting. The production quality is low. The enthusiasm is sincere. Mavrokka is the Cursed Generation captain most likely to inspire people who are not typically inspired by anything — dock workers, farmers, miners, people whose hands are calloused from work rather than training. Her fan community reflects this: the Mud Pit's demographics skew older, more working-class, and more mainland than any other CG fan community. When asked why, a Mud Pit moderator said: "She looks like someone I know. She fights like someone I know. She doesn't pretend she's more than she is."

---

## 9.13 THE ABSURD WORLD — Comedy, Chaos, and the Stupid Side of Greatness


*This world has genocides, seals on gods, and 3,000-year-old conspiracies. It also has people arguing about power rankings in taverns, a bounty hunter who weaponizes bar tabs, and a Conqueror who once set fire to her own ship by accident because she sneezed. The darkness and the absurdity are not separate. They are the same world. A world that is only dark is a world nobody wants to live in. A world that can laugh at itself while facing apocalypse is a world that feels real.*

---

### The Absurd Things That Are Canon

**The Vassago-Daeshara Debate:** The most heated argument in Grimoire history. Running for fifteen years. Has its own Black-band channel (4.2 million subscribers). Academic analyses have been published. Tavern brawls have been started. At least one marriage has ended over it. Vassago and Daeshara are both aware of the debate. Vassago has never commented. Daeshara posted a single response three years ago: "He's taller." This was interpreted by both sides as confirming their position. The debate intensified.

**Kuldhara's Sneeze Incident:** During a naval engagement in Year 5,576, Kuldhara sneezed mid-transformation. The Raiju Fruit's lightning arced uncontrollably, struck her own ship's mast, and set the sail on fire. Her crew put it out in four minutes. The opposing Wardensea commander was so confused he forgot to attack. Kuldhara re-engaged with a burning mast, won the fight in nine minutes, and spent the evening getting roasted by her crew at dinner. Gorreth (her son, then 11) told the story on an open Grimoire frequency. 200 million views. Kuldhara has threatened to ground him approximately 400 times since. He has never been grounded.

**The Gorundai Who Won't Stay Down:** Kolvessen Drauth (Daeshara's first ally) once held a mountain pass for eleven hours against a force of 300. When asked how, he said: "They kept coming. I kept standing. Eventually they got tired before I did." When pressed for tactical detail: "I hit the first one. Then I hit the second one. Then I hit the third one. At some point I lost count. Around four hundred, I think." He did not fight 400 people. He fought approximately 80 in rotating shifts. He genuinely does not know the difference and does not care.

**Dessaren Goltieri's Recruitment Record:** Seven attempts to recruit Kuorren. Four to recruit Kuldhara. Eleven to recruit various Cursed Generation captains. Three to recruit a specific bartender in Selvaggio who makes the best rum punch in the Bastion Sea. The bartender has declined all three. Dessaren finds this more personally insulting than any rejection from a Conqueror.

**Brundak Kesh's Method:** The most successful volume bounty hunter in the Kingsrun captures targets by buying them drinks until they pass out. Annual income: 300 million+ Sovereigns. Kill count: zero. Fight count: zero. Bar tab: classified. When asked by a Grimoire interviewer how he handles dangerous targets: "Everyone's dangerous until the fourth drink. After the sixth, nobody is." Has been doing this for twelve years. The Wardensea has never been able to charge him with anything because technically, buying someone a drink isn't a crime.

**Orvan Kess's Medical Papers:** The Lockstep crew's doctor has published eleven papers in the Gannavar Medical Journal while serving aboard a Renegade ship. Three papers cite "live field observations during hostile engagement." Paper #7, "Arterial Compression Under Extreme G-Force: A Case Study," was written during a ship chase where Pollen took the *Median* through a reef gap at speed. The paper includes the sentence: "The subject experienced a 4.2g lateral force event lasting 11 seconds, during which the attending physician (the author) also experienced 4.2g lateral force and can confirm the theoretical predictions regarding vision narrowing were optimistic." Peer reviewers have requested to visit the research facility. Orvaan has declined.

**Hallessen Mursk's Note:** The Lockstep Gorundai who doesn't speak wrote Ghellen Tousch one compliment in three years: "You are adequate." She framed it. It hangs in the mess. Every new visitor asks about it. Ghellen tells the story every time. Hallessen has never acknowledged the frame. He has also never asked her to take it down.

**The Bones Argument:** The dice game *bones* is universal across every Renegade crew. The rules are simple. The arguments about the rules are infinite. Every ship has a slightly different version. Cross-crew games at port inevitably produce rule disputes that escalate into shouting matches, then fistfights, then drinking together, then playing another round with DIFFERENT rules that produce new disputes. The longest recorded bones argument lasted nine hours and involved a Wardensea Lieutenant and a bounty hunter who were technically supposed to be trying to arrest each other. They finished the game first. The bounty hunter won. The Lieutenant paid up and THEN attempted the arrest. The bounty hunter escaped during the confusion of counting change.

---

### Absurd Grimoire Culture

**Power Rankings:** The Black-band hosts approximately 2,000 active power-ranking channels. None of them agree. Rankings are updated after every major fight, Grimoire clip, or rumor. The arguments are vicious, passionate, and based on an extremely sophisticated understanding of Dominion mechanics combined with an extremely unsophisticated understanding of how real fights work. The most popular ranking channel ("The Absolute List," 14M followers) once placed a Rathai engineer above a Wardensea Commandant because "technical creativity beats raw Dominion output in enclosed spaces." This produced a 48-hour flame war that crashed two Grimoire relay stations.

**Phonk Edits:** Gorune Vassik ("The Phonk King") invented the combat phonk edit — slow-motion fight footage set to bass-heavy music with dramatic captions. His edit of Kuldhara's Awakening (900M views) is the most-watched piece of content in Grimoire history. Kuldhara sent him storm tea in appreciation. He has since made edits of all five Conquerors. Senmovar's is 47 seconds of dark ocean footage with no visible combat. It has 340 million views. The comments are 90% "what am I looking at" and 10% "exactly."

**Cooking Channels:** Ship food Grimoire channels are the third most popular content category after combat footage and bounty analysis. Lessen Garval (Gannet Crew) didn't mean to become famous for his cooking — his reef-kelp stew was filmed by Tuuma as background content and went unexpectedly viral. He now receives ingredient requests at every port. Three Grimoire food critics have rated his sulfur-salt dried fish as "the best thing produced by a Renegade crew, and yes that includes the combat." Lessen finds this baffling. His crew finds it hilarious. His stew recipe has been replicated on 40,000 ships. None of them get it right. Lessen won't tell them why.

**Fan Ships:** Romantic pairing speculation between Renegade captains is a major Grimoire genre. The most popular pairing (Tomoe/Mavrokka, dubbed "BullFox" by fans) has produced approximately 12,000 pieces of fan art, despite the fact that the two have met exactly once (at Brannach — they argued about directions, Mavrokka called Tomoe short, Tomoe called Mavrokka's horn "lopsided," and they were separated by their crews before the island caught fire). Neither has commented on the pairing. Tuuma Kessav, Tomoe's Grimoire specialist, has liked seven BullFox posts. Tomoe does not know this. When she finds out, someone is getting thrown overboard.

---

### Absurd Power Moments

**Dominion Training Goes Wrong:** Every Dominion practitioner has a story about training going sideways. The most common: attempting Iron for the first time and either hardening nothing (embarassing) or hardening the wrong thing (painful). Sight overextension — reaching too far and picking up sensory input from every living thing within range — produces what practitioners call "the migraine of god." King training mishaps are the most spectacular: a first-time King manifestation that accidentally clears a tavern, knocks out a flock of seabirds, or — in one documented case — caused every dog in a three-block radius to sit down simultaneously.

**God Fruit Absurdity:** Every God Fruit user has discovered at least one useless secondary application of their power. Suuba Mettani's Kindling Fruit can ignite any flammable material in line of sight — which means she can light a pipe from across the room, warm a cold meal by igniting the spices, or start a campfire without matches. She once ended a tense negotiation by lighting the opposing captain's hat on fire. "It was distracting me." The hat survived. The negotiation did not.

Ressaven Delvun's Measure Fruit perceives all physical quantities as numbers. ALL of them. He knows the exact temperature of his soup, the precise weight of his crew's luggage, the RPM of the ship's rudder, and the exact number of barnacles on the hull (currently 11,847 — he checks daily and it bothers him). He cannot turn this off. Meeting new people is overwhelming: he immediately knows their height, weight, heart rate, body temperature, and the mass of whatever they're carrying. "Hello, you weigh 84.3 kilograms and your left boot is 200 grams heavier than your right." "Please stop." "I can't."

Calmund's Ledger Fruit records witnessed physical actions and replays them. He once accidentally recorded a bar fight and has been able to replay the losing fighter's exact combination of stumbles for two years. He uses it as a party trick. The fighter in question is a regular at Montalvo docks and has not forgiven him.

**Korvaan Side Effects:** Ironset Korvaan practitioners have bones denser than normal — which means they sink faster in water, set off weight-based security traps, and break chairs. The number of chairs broken by Korvaan practitioners in Kingsrun taverns has been estimated at 400-600 per year. Most taverns in the Mid-Kingsrun have reinforced seating. The Ossengaard fortress mess hall has stone benches. They were not always stone benches.

---

### Running Gags, Traditions, and World-Level Stupidity

**The Wardensea Coat Curse:** A running superstition among Wardensea enlisted: if a Lieutenant's storm-grey coat blows off during their earning ceremony, their first command will be a disaster. Statistical analysis (conducted by a bored Grimoire user with too much time) shows this has happened 14 times in 200 years. Twelve of those fourteen officers had notably difficult first commands. The Wardensea officially denies the superstition. Wardensea tailors unofficially add extra collar buttons.

**The Selvaggio Betting Board:** The first Kingsrun stop has a public betting board outside Departure Row's most popular tavern. Bets posted for every departing crew: how far they'll make it, how fast, who'll fight who, and which crew member will be the first to get sick. The betting board has been running for 90 years. It is technically illegal (unlicensed gambling). The Wardensea garrison commander has placed bets on it personally (under a pseudonym that everyone recognizes).

**Senmovar's Birthday:** Nobody knows when Senmovar was born. He is 241. His crew does not celebrate his birthday. Once every few years, Velesse Thorrath leaves a small cake outside his quarters. It is always gone by morning. Neither of them has ever mentioned it. The Undertow's other captains have attempted to determine Senmovar's birthday for approximately 80 years. They have formed a betting pool. The current leading theory (Drossen Kethvaine's, based on astronomical analysis of Morventhi naming conventions) places it in mid-autumn. Senmovar has not confirmed or denied this because no one has had the courage to ask him.

**Thessan Mulvar's King Problem:** The 23-year-old half-Gorundai in Vassago's inner circle has Prime-tier King with a 300-meter radius. He also has imperfect control. During his first week aboard the *Corsair*, his King manifested during a nightmare and knocked out everyone on the lower deck. Fifteen crew members woke up on the floor with splitting headaches. Thessan was still asleep. Kanneth Durro (the Leviathan Fruit user, 80 feet tall in full form) was the only person unaffected because he was sleeping in the water alongside the ship. He poked his head above the railing, saw everyone unconscious, saw Thessan snoring, and went back to sleep. The crew now takes shifts sleeping near Thessan with earplugs and resentment.

**The Gannet Crew's Coat Rule:** Tomoe wears her stolen Wardensea coat everywhere. It has never been washed. It smells. The crew has attempted an intervention three times. The first intervention was voted down (Tomoe threatened to throw the coat overboard, and everyone panicked because they realized the coat IS the crew's brand). The second intervention resulted in Durven Ossk being assigned permanent laundry duty for suggesting it. The third intervention involved Koddren "Smalls" Petch attempting to wash the coat while Tomoe slept. Her Sight woke her at the four-second mark. Smalls was found on the mast at dawn, hung by his own belt, coat safely on Tomoe's back. They have not tried again.

*The world is ending. The seal is cracking. The sovereign is dying. The truth about the genocide is surfacing. The Cursed Generation is sailing toward the unknown. And somewhere on the Kingsrun, a Gorundai is arguing with a Rathai about the rules of bones while their captain screams at a seagull that stole her hardtack. This is the world. All of it. At once.*
